Funci√≥n: Bloque de codigo que esta nombrado. 

```{r}
pow_two <- function(x, print_info=TRUE){
y <- x^2
if(print_info){
  print(paste(x,"to the power two equals", y))
}
return (y)
}

result <- pow_two (3)
result


```

Function scoping

```{r}
pow_two <- function (x){
  y <- x^2
  return (y)
}

pow_two(4)


```
R passes arguments by value

```{r}
tripe <- function(x){
  x <- 3*x
  x
}

a <- 5
tripe(a)
a


```

Other type of parameters

```{r}
linkedin <- c(16,9,13,5,2,17,14)

interpret <- function(num_views){
  if(num_views>15){
    print ("you are popular!")
    return (num_views)
  }
  else{
    print("Try to be more visible!")
    return(0)
  }
}

interpret(linkedin[1])

interpret_all <- function(views, return_sum=TRUE){
  count <- 0
  
  for (v in views){
    count <- count + interpret(v)
  }
  
  if (return_sum){
    return(count)
  }else {
    return(NULL)
  }
}

interpret_all (linkedin)

```

Use Apply with R

Lapply

```{r}
temp <- list(c(3,7,9,6,1), c(6,9,12,13,5), c(4,8,3,-1,-3), c(1,4,7,2,-2), c(5,7,9,4,2), c(-3,5,8,9,4), c(3,6,9,4,1))

select <- function (x){
  print (mean(x))
  
}

list <- lapply (temp, select)
list()

lapply(temp,min)



```

otra forma de hacer lo que hizo Lappy es con un ciclo for:

```{r}
for (t in temp){
  print(min(t))
}
```
